title: UTG Open with AKo
actionHistory: Folds to Hero in UTG
explanation: AKo is a premium hand that should always be opened from any position. From UTG, a standard 2.5BB raise is optimal. AKo has excellent equity against calling ranges and plays well postflop with its ability to make top pair top kicker.

title: BTN Open with 76s
actionHistory: Folds to Hero on BTN
explanation: 76s is a profitable open from the button. With position and a hand that can make straights, flushes, and two pairs, this is a standard open. The button is the most profitable position to open wide from due to guaranteed postflop position.

title: BB Defend vs BTN Open
actionHistory: BTN raises to 2.5BB, SB folds, Hero in BB
explanation: J9s has enough equity to defend the big blind at a favorable price. You're getting 2.3:1 on a call and J9s has good playability with straight and flush potential. 3-betting would also be reasonable but calling is the highest EV play against a wide BTN range.

title: CO 3-Bet with QQ
actionHistory: UTG raises to 2.5BB, Hero in CO
explanation: QQ is a premium hand that should almost always 3-bet. Against an UTG open, QQ has excellent equity and benefits from building the pot preflop. A 3-bet to ~8BB is standard sizing. Flatting allows other players to enter cheaply and reduces your positional advantage.

title: C-Bet on Dry Flop
actionHistory: Hero raised BTN, BB called. Flop: K♠ 7♣ 2♦. BB checks.
explanation: With top pair top kicker on a dry board, a continuation bet is standard. This board heavily favors the preflop raiser's range. A ~2/3 pot c-bet extracts value from worse kings, pocket pairs, and gets folds from missed hands. There are very few draws to worry about.

title: Bluff Catch on River
actionHistory: BTN raised, Hero called BB. Flop: A♠ 8♣ 3♦ check-check. Turn 5♥: Hero bet 4BB, BTN called. River 9♣: Hero checks, BTN bets 18BB.
explanation: AJ is near the top of your checking range on this river. The 9♣ completing the backdoor club draw gives villain some bluff candidates. You're getting ~2.3:1 on a call, needing ~30% equity. Against a balanced villain range of value (sets, two pair) and bluffs (missed draws, floats), AJ is a mandatory bluff catch.

title: Turn Barrel with Nut Flush Draw
actionHistory: Hero raised CO, BB called. Flop K♥ 9♥ 3♣: Hero bet 4BB, BB called. Turn J♦: BB checks.
explanation: With the nut flush draw, you have 9 clean outs (~19% equity) plus fold equity. Betting the turn as a semi-bluff is highly profitable. You'll win immediately when villain folds, and when called you still have strong equity to improve on the river. A ~3/4 pot bet applies maximum pressure.

title: Facing 3-Bet with AJs
actionHistory: Hero raises BTN to 2.5BB. BB 3-bets to 9BB.
explanation: AJs is too strong to fold but not strong enough to 4-bet (which would turn it into a bluff against BB's 3-bet range). Calling keeps in all of villain's bluffs and weaker 3-bets while maintaining good playability with position. AJs has excellent nut potential with the suited ace.

title: Check-Raise Bluff on Flop
actionHistory: CO raised, Hero called BB. Flop 8♠ 7♦ 2♠: Hero checks, CO bets 4BB.
explanation: 65s has a massive draw here: open-ended straight draw + flush draw = 15 outs. This is the perfect hand to check-raise as a semi-bluff. You have ~54% equity against villain's c-bet range, making this nearly a value raise. Check-raising also denies equity from villain's overcards and builds a pot for when you hit.

title: Overpair on Wet Board
actionHistory: Hero raised UTG, BTN called. Flop 9♥ 8♥ 3♣: Hero?
explanation: JJ is an overpair on a board with many draws. A c-bet of ~70% pot is standard to charge draws (flush draws, straight draws) and protect your equity. On a wet board, checking risks giving free cards. JJ is ahead of most of BTN's calling range but vulnerable to improvement.

title: Facing River Overbet
actionHistory: Hero raised CO, BTN called. Flop 9♦ 6♣ 2♠ check-check. Turn 4♥: Hero bet 6BB, BTN called. River Q♠: Hero checks, BTN bets 30BB (1.5x pot).
explanation: An overbet on this river polarizes villain's range to very strong hands (QQ, Q9, sets, straights) or bluffs. TT with a Q on board is in an awkward middle — it beats bluffs but loses to all value. At 1.5x pot, you need ~40% equity. Against a balanced overbet range, TT doesn't meet the threshold. Stronger bluff-catchers (AQ, KQ) should be called first.

title: SB Complete with K9o
actionHistory: Folds to Hero in SB
explanation: From the SB vs BB, K9o is strong enough to raise. Limping (completing) is generally suboptimal in modern poker as it gives BB a free option to realize equity. Raising to 3BB puts pressure on BB and takes the initiative. K9o has reasonable high-card strength for heads-up play.

title: Set on Paired Board
actionHistory: Hero raised BTN, BB called. Flop 8♥ 5♠ 5♦: Hero bet 3BB, BB called. Turn K♣: BB checks.
explanation: You have a full house (8s full of 5s) — one of the strongest possible hands. Bet for value! The K on the turn is an excellent card as it hits villain's calling range (Kx hands). A ~70% pot bet extracts value while keeping worse hands in. Don't slow-play — build the pot with a strong hand.

title: Pocket Aces Multiway
actionHistory: UTG raises to 2.5BB, MP calls.
explanation: With AA, you always want to 3-bet, especially multiway. Flatting allows more players in and reduces your equity significantly — AA goes from ~85% vs 1 opponent to ~65% vs 2. A 3-bet to ~10BB isolates and builds the pot with the best possible hand. You want the pot heads-up and as large as possible.

title: River Value Bet with Two Pair
actionHistory: Hero raised BTN, BB called. Flop K♦ J♥ 4♣: BB check, Hero bet 4BB, BB called. Turn 7♠: BB check, Hero bet 8BB, BB called. River 2♥: BB checks.
explanation: KJ for two pair is a clear value bet on this brick river. Villain has called flop and turn, indicating a hand like Kx, Jx, or a pocket pair. Many of these hands will call another bet. Betting ~75% pot maximizes value from worse hands while not overcommitting in case villain has a set or better two pair.

title: Folding ATo UTG
actionHistory: Hero in UTG (9-handed)
explanation: ATo is a marginal hand from UTG at a 9-handed table. With 8 players left to act, there's a significant chance of running into a dominating hand (AJ+, TT+). ATo plays poorly out of position multiway and makes dominated top pairs. In modern GTO solutions, ATo is a fold from UTG.

title: Defending vs 4-Bet
actionHistory: Hero raises BTN to 2.5BB, BB 3-bets to 10BB, Hero 4-bets to 22BB, BB shoves all-in for 100BB.
explanation: A5s is used as a 4-bet bluff due to its ace blocker and suit, but facing a 5-bet shove, it's a clear fold. Villain's 5-bet range is extremely strong (typically AA, KK, QQ, AK). A5s has only ~30% equity against this range, and you're risking 78BB more to win 23BB. The pot odds don't justify a call.

title: Donk Bet Spot
actionHistory: BTN raised, Hero called BB. Flop 5♥ 4♦ 3♣: Hero to act.
explanation: You flopped the nut straight on a board that heavily favors the BB's range. This is one of the rare spots where a donk bet (leading into the preflop raiser) is correct. The board connects with BB's calling range (suited connectors, small pairs) much more than BTN's raising range. Leading lets you build the pot and start charging draws.

title: Thin Value on River
actionHistory: Hero raised CO, BB called. Flop Q♣ 8♠ 4♦: Hero bet 5BB, BB called. Turn 3♥: check-check. River 6♣: BB checks.
explanation: QJ is in a great spot for a thin value bet. After BB called the flop and both checked the turn, BB's range includes Qx worse kicker, 8x, and pocket pairs 99-JJ. These hands will often call a ~half pot river bet. While you may occasionally run into Q8 or a set, you're ahead of enough of villain's range to make this profitable.

title: ICM Spot: Bubble Play
actionHistory: Tournament bubble (4 left, 3 paid). Hero has 25BB in CO. BTN (big stack, 80BB) raises to 2.5BB. SB folds.
explanation: AQo is a premium hand on the bubble and too strong to fold. With 25BB, the correct play is to 3-bet all-in. Calling bloats the pot out of position with a hand that plays well as an all-in. The big stack's BTN range is wide, and AQo has excellent equity against it. ICM pressure actually works for you here — the big stack risks busting you but has less incentive to call light.

title: Facing Flop Check-Raise
actionHistory: Hero raised BTN, BB called. Flop T♦ 6♣ 3♠: BB checks, Hero bets 4BB, BB raises to 12BB.
explanation: T9s with top pair and decent kicker is too strong to fold but not strong enough to 3-bet (which would commit you with a marginal holding). BB's check-raise range includes sets, two pairs, and semi-bluffs with straight draws. Calling keeps in all bluffs and lets you reassess on the turn. Position gives you a significant advantage going forward.

title: Polarized 3-Bet with A5s
actionHistory: CO raises to 2.5BB, BTN folds, SB folds, Hero in BB.
explanation: A5s is an ideal 3-bet bluff from the BB. It has an ace blocker (reducing the chances villain has AA/AK), suit connectivity for postflop playability, and can flop nut flushes and straights. In a polarized 3-betting strategy, hands like A5s/A4s balance your value 3-bets (QQ+, AK) to keep villain guessing.

title: Multi-Street Bluff Decision
actionHistory: Hero raised BTN, BB called. Flop A♠ 9♣ 4♥: Hero bet 4BB, BB called. Turn 2♥: BB checks.
explanation: KQhh picked up the nut flush draw on the turn, giving you 9 outs plus two overcards. This is an excellent spot to barrel. You can win by: (1) villain folding right now, (2) hitting your flush on the river, or (3) bluffing the river if a heart comes. The combination of fold equity + draw equity makes this a clear bet.

title: Slow-Playing the Nuts
actionHistory: BTN raised, Hero called BB. Flop 9♥ 3♣ 2♦: Hero to act.
explanation: With top set on a very dry board, checking is optimal. There are almost no draws to worry about, so slow-playing costs very little in terms of equity denial. By checking, you let the preflop raiser c-bet (which they should do frequently on this board), and you can then check-call to keep their bluffs in and set up for a check-raise on the turn or a big river bet.
